content.title: Anterior Lumbar Spine Access (ALIF Exposure)
content.definition: Surgical exposure of the anterior lumbar spine (L4-S1) through retroperitoneal or transperitoneal approaches, providing access for spinal fusion procedures while protecting major vascular structures.

key_concepts.description: Access through the retroperitoneal space, avoiding entry into the peritoneal cavity. Used for L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels.
Access through the peritoneal cavity, typically via laparoscopy or open midline incision. Provides wider exposure but carries higher risk of bowel injury.
Left common iliac vein lies directly over L4-L5 disc space. Iliolumbar vein is a critical structure requiring ligation in most cases.
Aortic bifurcation typically at L4 level (range L3-L5). Must be identified preoperatively on CT/MRI to plan approach.

technique.positioning: Supine with slight Trendelenburg. Hip flexion reduces psoas tension.

vascular_mobilization.L5-S1: Mobilize left common iliac artery and vein leftward. Middle sacral vessels require ligation.
vascular_mobilization.L4-L5: Ligate and divide iliolumbar vein. Mobilize left common iliac vein. Careful retraction of great vessels.
vascular_mobilization.L3-L4: Requires aortic mobilization. Higher risk level. Consider lateral approach.

critical_steps: Ligate iliolumbar vein (prevents avulsion during retraction)
Gentle vessel retraction - avoid prolonged ischemia
Confirm segmental vessel ligation if needed

arterial.injury_prevention: Meticulous dissection, self-retaining retractors with padded blades, avoid excessive traction

venous.injury_prevention: Iliolumbar vein ligation mandatory at L4-L5. Gentle retraction. Low-pressure hemostasis.

vascular.management: Immediate pressure, vascular surgery consultation, primary repair vs graft

neurological.sympathetic_injury: Retrograde ejaculation in males (2-5% with L5-S1 exposure)
neurological.prevention: Stay midline, identify and preserve hypogastric plexus

outcomes.hospital_stay: Typically 2-4 days with combined spine team

learning_objectives: Describe the retroperitoneal anatomy relevant to anterior lumbar spine access
Identify key vascular structures at L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels
Explain the importance of iliolumbar vein ligation
List vascular complications and their management

common_misconceptions.misconception: All spine levels can be accessed through the same approach
common_misconceptions.correction: L5-S1 typically retroperitoneal; L3-L4 may require lateral or higher transperitoneal approach

clinical_pearls: Always ligate the iliolumbar vein before retracting at L4-L5
Preoperative CT defines bifurcation level and variant anatomy
Left-sided approach preferred - liver limits right-sided access
